title: Sleep and immune function, chronotypes, hygiene tips, and addressing questions about his book
content: In this episode, sleep expert Matthew Walker returns by popular demand to dive deeper into many sleep-related topics, starting with what we’ve learned about sleep through the lens of the COVID-19 pandemic and how sleep impacts the immune system. He then covers topics such as how dreaming affects emotional health, the different sleep chronotypes, the best sleep hygiene tips, and the pros and cons of napping. Matthew finishes by addressing several of the errors that readers have pointed out in his book, Why We Sleep.

title: The Physiology of Stress Response
content: Robert Sapolsky, Ph.D., discusses the widespread impact of stress on our physical and emotional health as well as the mechanisms by which it can precipitate chronic illness, dementia, depression, and more. He also provides insight into the factors that contribute to the stress response (and our ability to handle it) such as social rank, personality, environment, and genetics.

title: The Impact of Stress on Health
content: Robert Sapolsky, Ph.D., discusses the impact of stress on atherosclerosis, dementia, addiction, and depression. He also talks about the role of stress in cancer and how it can lead to chronic illness.

title: Tips for Managing Stress
content: Robert Sapolsky, Ph.D., provides tips for managing stress in the modern world. He talks about the impact of subjective socioeconomic status and social media on stress levels and health.

title: Impact of COVID-19 on Sleep
content: The COVID-19 pandemic has impacted sleep in 3 ways: the amount that people are sleeping, the timing of the sleep, and dreaming. A sleep tracking company found total sleep time had increased across the entire country by ~20%. Two peer-reviewed papers from Current Biology added more nuance—1-Total amount of sleep had increased by 15 minutes, 2-Social “jet lag” had decreased. People are sleeping more during the week without those same week-day obligations and their “sleep opportunity” has increased. Subjective sleep quality had decreased in a subset of people.

title: Importance of Dreaming for Emotional Health
content: Dreaming has increased since the pandemic began. Dreaming allows for the purging negative emotion or stress. Two principle types of sleep are non-REM sleep and REM sleep. REM sleep is typically associated with dreaming. These are the dreams we think of as narrative-based, emotionally-filled, bizarre, hallucinogenic, dreams.

title: The Architecture of Sleep
content: The majority of the 90-minute sleep cycles in the first half of the night are comprised of deep non-REM sleep (stages 3 and 4) and very little REM sleep. In the second half of the night, the majority of those 90-minute cycles are comprised of REM sleep.

title: How Coronavirus Pandemic Increased Dreaming
content: People are sleeping in a little bit later into the morning, which means that they’re now sleeping further into that REM sleep rich window of the night. Dreaming is a way that we purge negative emotion or stress in some way. One of the principle functions of rapid eye movement sleep is that it seems to provide a form of overnight therapy.

title: The Impact of Alcohol Consumption on Sleep Quality and Stress Levels
content: Peter has found himself consuming more alcohol during the pandemic – he thinks it’s probably stress related. Using his Oura ring, Peter can clearly see that his sleep quality suffers if he has more than one drink too close to bedtime. Alcohol disproportionately negatively impacts REM sleep, which is the medicine needed to de-risk the emotional experiences and the anxiety that’s building up.

title: Sleep and Immune Function
content: We know that sleep improves immune function, but have we learned anything new with respect to COVID? Matt says that we don’t have any direct data yet regarding how a lack of sleep impacts your vulnerability to COVID, or if you are infected, the severity of progression. This classic study showed that individuals getting less than seven hours of sleep a night are almost three times more likely to become infected by the rhinovirus (common cold). A large prospective study of over 50,000 women found that women who were sleeping 5 hours or less were 70% more likely to develop pneumonia (a component risk in the equation of COVID). Mouse study suggesting a causal relationship: When mice are selectively deprived mice of various stages of sleep (particularly REM sleep) and exposed to malaria, they were far more likely to die as a consequence compared to the well-rested mice. A study looking at response to flu vaccines found that not getting sufficient sleep in the week before you get your flu shot resulted in producing less than 50% of the normal antibody response therefore rendering that flu vaccination significantly less effective.

title: Sleep and COVID-19 Vaccine
content: Matt’s point: We do need to be prospectively looking at this when the COVID-19 vaccine comes out by tracking sleep—if your sleep in the days before you get your COVID vaccination determines whether or not it’s successful, we should know that and we should be smart about it. Peter’s main point: If sleep could increase the efficacy of that vaccination by 50% (like sleep seems to due for flu vaccines) we should be very focused on that. Peter is hopeful that in the many phase 2 studies looking at coronavirus vaccines that someone will do a subgroup analysis on things like, How many soluble antibodies are you getting? What type of T cell response are you getting? And can we at least retrospectively look at the sleep quality going into that, if not prospectively?

title: Determining Sleep Cycles
content: For the average adult, one sleep cycle seems to be about 90 minutes. For some people it’s shorter, for some people it’s longer. Scientists actually don’t really understand what determines the length of your sleep cycle. But generally, the larger your brain mass relative to the rest of you, the longer your sleep schedule. That said, scientist have no idea why sleep plays out in this 90 minute cycle.

title: Determining Deep Sleep and REM Sleep
content: For deep, non-REM sleep— How much deep sleep you need/get is determined by how long you’ve been awake and only a little bit on the basis of your circadian rhythm. How long you’ve been away is much more deterministic of i) how much deep sleep and ii) how deep that deep sleep is going to be. REM sleep— REM sleep is much more powerfully determined by the circadian time of night and is less determined by how long you’ve been awake.

title: The role of melatonin, cortisol, and adenosine in how much deep sleep you need
content: Little bit of a function of the accumulation of melatonin. Somewhat a function of how much cortisol you’ve managed to suppress. Very much a function of the accumulation of adenosine. Adenosine is a chemical that starts building up in your brain the moment you wake up. And the longer the amount of clock time that your brain has been awake, the more adenosine builds up. This produces what we call “sleep pressure”. That pressure, or sleepiness, is the weight of that chemical pressure of adenosine.

title: Pros and cons of napping, and insights from the sleep habits of hunter-gatherer tribes
content: Naps as short as 17 minutes can produce learning and memory benefits (unpublished data from Matt). And you can some benefit from a cardiovascular standpoint as well (unpublished data from Matt). Downside of naps is that it can take away which is sleep pressure which could exacerbate nighttime sleep issues. If you are struggling with falling asleep at night (sleep onset insomnia), avoid naps during the day. You want to build up as much sleep pressure/sleepiness as you possibly can during the day. On the flip side, if you are not struggling with your sleep at night, there’s no problem with napping regularly during the day. If you study hunter-gatherer tribes (whose way of life hasn’t changed for thousands of years), they don’t necessarily sleep the way that we do today. During the summer months, they will typically have an afternoon nap. This make sense because when you study human brains you see that somewhere between about 2:00 to 4:00 PM we have a drop in physiological alertness. As a species, we’re almost pre-programmed to have this enforced dip in our alertness suggesting maybe we should be biphasically sleeping (as opposed to monophasically sleeping) at certain times during the year. Typically pretty short, says Matt, less than 90 minutes. Hunter gatherers would typically sleep just six-and-a-half hours at night, and then they would make the rest up with an afternoon nap (which matches most sleep experts recommendation that we get 7-9 hours per night).

title: Comparing humans to primates
content: It makes sense that primates have less REM sleep because they sleep in trees. They can’t afford a lot of the loss of muscle tone that comes with REM sleep otherwise they might fall out of the trees.

title: Sleep Hygiene Tips
content: Regularity: Going to bed at the same time, waking up at the same time. Light: Getting lots of darkness at night because we are a dark-deprived society (and making sure you get daylight during the first half of the day)Temperature: You need to get cool to get to sleep“Walk it out”: Don’t lie awake in bed because trains your brain to be triggered by your bed and force you awake because you have a learned association (TIP: If you’ve been awake for 20 minutes, then get up, go and do something else and only come back to bed when you’re sleepy)Alcohol/caffeine: Avoid alcohol and caffeine too close to bedtime

title: Additional Advice for Optimizing Sleep
content: 1—Wind-down routineThis is absolutely critical to build it into your routine, says MattMany people in society expect sleep to be like a light switch — it’s just not like thatA routine might be 15 minutes for some, others it’s 30 minutesThings like light stretches, meditation, putting all of your phones and your gadgets away can be apart of the routine2—Remove clock facesIf you are struggling with sleep, remove all clock faces from your bedroomKnowing that it’s now 2:35 AM in the morning is only going to trigger more anxietyThis study from UC Berkeley by Allison Harvey showed that removing clock faces was helpful for poor sleepers with insomnia3—Remove technology from the bedroomTechnology (esp. phones) can cause “anticipatory anxiety”Don’t make checking your phone (e.g., emails, texts, etc.) the first thing you do in the morningThis trains your brain in a “Pavlovian way” that even as your tucking yourself in bed at night to expect that anxiety waiting for you on your side table This “anticipatory anxiety” actually lightens your sleep throughout the night because of that expectationTechnology can result in “sleep procrastination”Example would be scrolling through your phone looking for that next interesting thing and procrastinating the process of putting your mind to restTip from Matt’s colleague, Michael Grandner: If you’re going to have your phone in your bedroom, make it a rule that you can only use it if you’re standing up. After 5-10 minutes of standing you just think, “God, I just want to sit down. I just want to get into bed.”4—Set manageable goalsMatt references BJ Fogg, a researcher at Stanford, who looks at behavioral change and applies it to sleep—If you are accustomed to checking your phone the moment you wake up, try to start by giving yourself five minutes without checking itNext, keep pushing it longer and longer (10 min, 20 min, and so on)Don’t set yourself up for failure, ease into it and set yourself up for success

title: Understanding Sleep Chronotypes
content: Determining and understanding sleep chronotypeYour sleep chronotype simply means—Are you a morning person? (25-30% of the population)Are you an evening person? (25-30% of the population)Or are you somewhere in between? (the rest of us 40-50%)Sleep science breaks it into 4 categories:Extreme morning typesMorning typesMiddle evening typesExtreme evening typesGenetic-component of sleep chronotypesEvidence that it’s genetic:

title: Genes that determine your chronotype
content: Data from 23andMe says there’s about 9 different genes that will contribute to your chronotype. These genes are what we call “clock genes”—This refers to the fact that these genes control the rhythm of your circadian cycle. These genes control WHEN that sinusoidal wave of your circadian cycle arrives on the clock face. Said another way, if you have a certain type of gene compliment that makes you a morning type, your peak alertness is going to arrive earlier in the day and the downstroke of your circadian rhythm will arrive earlier in the evening. In other words, your circadian rhythm looks very similar in its sinusoidal pattern but WHEN the peak and the trough of that circadian rhythm arrive on the 24 hour clock face is very different to a morning type compared to an evening type.

title: Evolution of the sleep-wake cycle over your lifetime
content: No matter what chronotype you are, you will change as you develop from a young child to an adolescent teen, to an adult, to an older adult. More of a morning type when you’re a kid. A teen’s chronotype makes your bedtime later and your wake time later in the morning (sleeping more in total). Once you become an adult, bedtime becomes a little earlier. As we get older, we tend to go to bed earlier and earlier (with earlier wake times).

title: Your innate chronotype can still be twisted/contorted by non-genetic forces
content: Examples—modern social norms, light exposure, technology, etc.) Interesting experiment: A camping study during Winter. At the end of the week, their melatonin levels began to rise 2.6 hours earlier. Going to be much earlier (more than two hours). But they did NOT wake earlier. As a result, they got 2.3 hours more sleep (~9 hr was the median). NOTE: This may not be realistic to normal life. And if you do the same in experiment in Summer you don’t get as dramatic an effect b/c of so much sun (almost like solstice effect in Scandinavia).

title: How to determine your sleep chronotype
content: Paid genetic test like 23andMe. Free online survey: MEQ test – Decent approximation (concordance) with genetic tests.

title: How knowing your chronotype could benefit you
content: With that said, how would knowing your sleep chronotype provide a benefit? 1—It would explain a lot about why you might struggle so much where other people seem to be just these energizer bunnies. 2—Realizing that you’re not culpable, it’s not your fault. E.g., A lot of night owls have gone throughout life being chastised. Matt says society really needs to be much more understanding and then also modify how we do things in response. 3—It can sometimes explain incorrectly diagnosed insomnia. “When you fight biology, you normally lose. The way you know you’ve lost is often through disease and sickness.”

title: Night terrors in kids—what they are and why they happen
content: Night terrors are typically where people (mostly kids) wake up with a terrible sense of dread and fear (the child is often inconsolable at that stage). Many parents report that young children seem to get sleep terrors (aka night terrors) when they are overly exhausted compared to when they are well-rested. The night terror events seem to happen during deep non-REM sleep (i.e., dreamless sleep) rather than during REM sleep (which might explain why the child rarely remembers anything). When a child spends an extended time being awake or miss a nap (i.e., they are exhausted), they will typically then have a homeostatic increase in the amount of deep sleep. So they’re probably going to go into deep non-REM sleep in a more intense fashion or with greater amounts of deep sleep duration. This therefore means that the probabilistic likelihood of them having one of these night terrors is increased as a consequence.

title: Addressing errors found in Matt’s book, Why We Sleep
content:
Matthew has just about completed a second addition to his bestselling book, Why We Sleep
In this edition, Matthew is addressing some of the errors that made it into his book
Matt has identified about 13 errors in the book that required correction
For context, the book contains over 1,000 facts
For those who don’t want to wait for the 2nd edition of the book, Matt has written a blog post describing all the errors and misinterpretations in the book along with a collection of detailed scientific literature

title: Mistakes in Why We Sleep
content:
1 | Regarding the association between sleep and cardiovascular disease
The book stated that a study looked at over half a million individuals, but in fact it was actually 474,684 individuals (so less than half a million)
2 | Regarding the relationship between short sleep and cancer risk
In the opening introduction of the book, Matt stated that short sleep can double your risk of cancer
To clarify, Matt says short sleep does not double your risk of all forms of cancer
Short sleep is associated with a doubling of a risk of specific forms of cancer, such as ovarian cancer or lung cancer
3 | Regarding the relationship between sleep deprivation and depression
In a subset of patients with depression, if we deprive them of sleep for one night, we get this really interesting paradoxical antidepressant benefit where it helps them
In fact, Matt has gone on to do MRI studies where we’ve tried to understand what is going on in the brain to produce this paradoxical antidepressant benefit
The issue in the book is that Matthew stated that somewhere between 30 to 40% of patients with depression will respond to sleep deprivation
But since the book was published, there’s been a meta-analysis that’s now shown that it’s not 30 to 40%, but rather 45%
4 | Regarding the relationship between sleep loss and cardiovascular disease
The book spoke about a study in over 4,000 individuals looking at cardiovascular disease
But in the study, it was only a subset of those patients, 2,282, that were analyzed for that analysis Matt described
5 | Regarding the relationship between sleep loss/short sleep and cardiac arrests
Matt stated short sleep was associated with an increased risk of cardiac arrests
But in the paper, they were reporting the increase in cardiac events, not cardiac arrests
So in addition to heart attacks, it also included other things like angina pectoris that required coronary bypass
6 | Regarding the relationship between long sleep and mortality risk
One of the things that is clear in the literature is that there is not a LINEAR relationship between sleep and mortality risk
So it’s not that the more and more sleep you get the lower your mortality risk
That is true up to a point, but once you get to nine hours and beyond, your mortality risk stops going down and actually starts to go up
This has led to the misinterpretation that long sleep is bad for you and that it’s associated with a faster death
The problem with the large epidemiological studies is that they had not measured all of the different disease outcomes in those studies
So when we get sick, the main thing that we want to do is curl up in bed and go to sleep. 
Why? 
It comes back to sleep and immune health because when you are sick, you release a whole collection of immune factors, particularly the cytokines that are sleep inducing
In other words, these patients were trying to “sleep themselves well” but whatever disease that they had was still too powerful and they still died
This artificially looked like long sleep was associated with a quicker death when in fact it could have been that long sleep was the thing that was desperately trying to save them, but failing in the end
In the book, that was the interpretation at the time, which Matt still believes to be true
The second way to think about this is that long sleep is also associated with poor quality sleep
Poor quality sleep, independent of length of sleep, is itself associated with mortality risk

title: The Link Between Sleep Quality and Mortality Risk
content: In other words, the lower and lower the quality of your sleep, the higher your risk of death. It’s also true that when people are not sleeping well, they typically try to stay in bed longer to try and get more sleep because the quality of their sleep is so bad. In this scenario, what’s happening is that poor quality of sleep is masquerading as long sleep, which is associated with higher risk of death. So it’s not really long sleep that’s the problem, it’s the poor quality of sleep that’s happening which results in people trying to stay in bed longer because they are still tired.

title: Nighttime Shift Work and Cancer Risk
content: Matt says that the World Health Organization had classified any form of nighttime shift work as a probable carcinogen (and confirmed that claim in a 2019 report). Fact checkers pointed out that is was actually the International Agency for Research on Cancer, the IARC, that made that statement and not the WHO. HOWEVER the IARC is actually part of the WHO, so Matt chalks this “error” up as a lack of clarity in his writing.
